• Validity of earlier court orders: Whether the order dated 1st June, 2013 of the District Court, Ernakulam dismissing the interim application is valid and binding on the parties?
• Interim injunctions: Whether the ex parte injunction granted in OS no. 12/2013 was properly vacated by the District Court, Ernakulam?
• Jurisdictional issues: Whether this court has jurisdiction to hear the present suits while an appeal (RFA 117/2017) is pending before the Kerala High Court?
• Stay of proceedings: Can the defendants seek a stay of the present suits under Section 10 of the CPC on the ground that a related appeal is pending in another high court?

• Trademark similarity: What is the test for determining whether two trademarks are deceptively similar or not?
• Trade dress infringement: Whether the defendants' use of a trade dress identical to the plaintiff's infringes upon the plaintiff's trade dress rights?

Here is a comprehensive summary of the case:

**Background:**

The plaintiff, V-Guard Industries Ltd., filed two lawsuits against defendants Rakesh Malhotra and Vave India Energy Solutions Private Limited claiming that they had infringed on their trade marks "V-GUARD" and "LIVGUARD", respectively. The lawsuits were CS(COMM) 1018/2016 and CS(COMM) 814/2018.

**Legal Issues:**

The main legal issue in this case was whether the defendants' use of the trade mark "LIVGUARD" was deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trade mark "V-GUARD". The plaintiff claimed that the defendant's mark was a trademark infringement and sought permanent injunction restraining the defendants from passing off their goods.

**History of Litigation:**

The parties have had a long history of litigation relating to their competing trademarks. In OS no. 12/2013, filed by the plaintiff alleging trademark infringement against Rakesh Malhotra (now defendant no.1 in CS(COMM) 1018/2016), an ex parte injunction was granted restraining him from using the trade mark "LIVGUARD". However, this was later vacated and the interim application was dismissed holding that there is no similarity between the plaintiff's trademark "V-GUARD" and the defendant's trademark "LIVGUARD".

**Arguments:**

The defendants filed two applications under Section 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure (CPC) for stay of the present suits till the disposal of the appeal bearing no. RFA 117/2017 before the Kerala High Court.

The senior counsel for the plaintiff stated that no reply was required to be filed to the aforesaid applications, while the defendants argued that there is no similarity between the plaintiff's trademark "V-GUARD" and their trade mark "LIVGUARD", as held by the District Court, Ernakulam and later reinforced by the Kerala High Court.

**Court Findings:**

The court found that:

1.  The defendant's application for stay was maintainable under Section 10 of CPC.
2.  The court considered that the appeal before the Kerala High Court would have significant bearing on this case, particularly as the judgment in OS no. 12/2013 (which had ex parte injunction initially granted) is pending before the High Court.
3.  The plaintiff has already approached the Kerala High Court and obtained dismissal of their SLP, and therefore it was considered just that the proceedings in Delhi should also be stayed.

**Decision:**

The court granted a stay to the present suits CS(COMM) 1018/2016 and CS(COMM) 814/2018 till disposal of appeal bearing no. RFA 117/2017 filed by the plaintiff before the Kerala High Court against the judgment and decree dated 22nd November, 2016 passed by the Additional District Judge, Ernakulam in OS No. 12/2013.

This order gives an impression that defendant's trademark "LIVGUARD" was not considered to be deceptively similar to V-GUARD, which is a subject matter of ongoing litigation in Kerala High Court. 

Decision of this case has been stayed till Kerala High Court decides case RFA 117/2017 so final decision remains pending.

contradictory verdicts by two courts in respect of the same relief

whether Section 10 was applicable or not, is to see whether on

On July 4, 2019, the defendants, including RML, Vave India Energy Solutions Pvt. Ltd., and SAR Group, moved to stay both suits due to a pending appeal in the Kerala High Court.
